key_insight: A modular teleoperation interface combined with a scalable learning framework and a choice-policy coordinator enables robust whole-body humanoid manipulation by decomposing control into intuitive submodules and learning how to coordinate them.
problem_solved: Addresses the challenge of achieving coordinated, whole-body control across head, hands, and legs for humanoid robots in human-centric environments, where coupling between multiple effectors makes end-to-end control brittle and data-hungry.
method: Design a modular teleoperation interface that decomposes humanoid control into submodules (hand-eye coordination, grasp primitives, arm end-effector tracking, locomotion).
Train a scalable learning framework that learns submodule policies from teleoperation data and uses a higher-level choice policy to select and coordinate submodules.
Integrate teleoperation, learned primitives, and the choice policy to enable seamless whole-body coordination during manipulation and locomotion tasks.
impact: Provides a practical blueprint for building scalable, interpretable humanoid control systems that reduce engineering complexity and improve robustness for whole-body tasks, helping practitioners transfer teleoperation expertise into learned policies.
visual_elements: Architecture diagram showing modular submodules (hands, arms, head, legs) with a central choice-policy coordinator
Pipeline flowchart: teleoperation → dataset → submodule training → choice-policy learning → deployment
Annotated humanoid illustration highlighting submodule roles (grasp, end-effector tracking, locomotion) and interaction arrows
Comparison chart (e.g., task success / robustness) contrasting coordinated modular approach vs. monolithic baselines
paper_title: Coordinated Humanoid Manipulation with Choice Policies
paper_authors: Haozhi Qi, Yen-Jen Wang, Toru Lin, Brent Yi, Yi Ma
